body: ''This is 'Brigadoon,' '' a resident of Howard Beach told a reporter a few years ago, when questions about the neighborhood were asked in a more innocent context. Yet now, in the aftermath of the beatings of three black men by a dozen whites, the comment has taken on a new and different resonance. For while Brigadoon was a paradise, as many in
title: IN HOWARD BEACH, PRIDE AND FEAR IN A 'PARADISE'

body: THE three-story brownstone at 110 Hart Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn is little more than a shell, a sagging husk without heat, hot water or toilets. Three families live there using buckets for plumbing. They heat themselves with barbecue charcoal. They light their grim rooms with pirated electricity carried by a web of
title: New York Plays Reluctant Landlord

body: Today Actors Outlet, 120 West 28th Street. ''The Dangerous Christmas of Red Riding Hood,'' a two-act musical version of the fairy tale from the wolf's viewpoint, with music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill, and book by Robert Emmett; Theater and Dance Alliance; directed by Lee Costello. At 7:30 P.M.; tomorrow at 1:30 and 4 P.M. and Sunday at 3
title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC EVENTS FOR THE CHRISTMAS SEASON; Other Christmas Offerings Around Town

body: Authorities investigating last week's murder of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial are studying a suspected link between the victim, Gaetano Mazzara, and an accused heroin dealer, according to police and Government investigators. They said the evidence suggested that Mr. Mazzara may have been involved in a heroin deal in August,
title: LINK OF 'PIZZA' MURDER VICTIM TO A HEROIN DEAL IS SUSPECTED

body: ''WE can turn out these buildings like pancakes,'' says Abram Gin. ''But the local authorities must cooperate.'' Counting each building as a pancake, Mr. Gin has turned out 60 over the last 10 years. He did not build them new. He took occupied structures built before World War II - most of them holding 50 or 60 apartments - and rehabilitated them,
title: PERSPECTIVES: PRESERVING HOUSING; The Turn in Rental Rehabilitation

body: A defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial who had been reported missing last Thursday was found slain yesterday, his body wrapped inside a plastic garbage bag and dumped on a Brooklyn street, the police said. The body of Gaetano Mazzara of Sayreville, N.J., a former restaurant owner accused of being a heroin supplier, was found yesterday
title: MISSING DEFENDANT IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL IS FOUND SLAIN

body: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 44 food establishments cited for violating the health code. In addition, it listed 14 restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for having failed to do so. title: 44 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS

body: Art shows are not as easy to come by in this sprawling borough as in cosy, prodigal Manhattan. There is the glorious Brooklyn Museum, to be sure, but after that, what? No SoHo, no TriBeCa, no Madison Avenue - in short, no gallery ''scene.'' Yet Brooklyn actually has a lot to offer in the way of exhibitions, and part of the fun is seeking them out.
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; Art Shows in Familiar and Unexpected Places

body: Manhattanites are generally wary of seeking out restaurants in the mysterious boroughs, or at least those establishments they can't see from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. That's just fine to the two-million-plus residents of Brooklyn - makes it easier to get a table. From the Middle Eastern enclaves of Atlantic Avenue to the Sicilian sections of
title: BROOKLYN'S BEST AND BRIGHTEST; At Restaurants, From Neapolitan Dishes to Middle Eastern Delicacies

body: When high winds from Hurricane Gloria buckled the old wooden steeple of the 134-year-old Reformed Church of South Bushwick in Brooklyn last year, leaving it tilting precariously, the tiny congregation quickly found that it could not finance the extensive repairs. Finally, after the 70-member congregation raised several hundred dollars, it turned to
title: FUND HELPS RESOTRE CITY'S CHURCHES

body: Two security guards hired to patrol shelters for the homeless in the Bronx and Brooklyn stabbed two homeless men to death in separate incidents this week and have been charged with murder, the police said yesterday. Both stabbings occurred after disputes broke out between the homeless men and the guards, who are not authorized to carry weapons, the
title: GUARDS HELD IN 2 SHELTER KILLINGS

body: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward is planning a large-scale transfer of supervisors, and possibly patrol officers, from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, where 13 officers have been suspended amid accusations of corruption and misconduct, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The officials said the transfer of supervisors, which might also involve
title: SHIFTS AT PRECINCT IN BROOKLYN SEEN

body: OUT with the old and in with the new is not as easy as it sounds - especially not in New York. What to do with unwanted refrigerators, discarded couches or oversize dining room sets are some of the trials of city dwelling. The Sanitation Department has established procedures for disposing of such bulk items. The department also hopes to stem
title: GETTING CITY HELP ON BULKY CASTOFFS

body: A crowd, including a group of scouts, gathered yesterday during dedication ceremonies for a square named in honor of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko. The square, which is adjacent to McCarren Park, is in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. Father Popieluszko, who became known as a patron of the union Solidarity and a human rights activist, was kidnapped
title: Honoring Polish Priest

body: When housing prices explode in Manhattan, the tremors shake neighborhoods like Greenpoint in Brooklyn. One of the city's best-preserved working-class areas, Greenpoint is now feeling the exponential rent increases, housing turnover and influx of young professionals that have characterized gentrification in New York City. Greenpoint offers a virtual
title: SIGNS OF TRANSFORMATION IN NEIGHBORLY GREENPOINT

body: THE WORLD The Kremlin accused the President of lacking the courage and will to take a historic step forward at the Reykjavik summit meeting. But Mikhail S. Gorbachev, on Soviet television, said he was not ending the search for arms control. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] The arms control talks collapsed after Mikhail S. Gorbachev toughened his bargaining
title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1986

body: LIKE a stretching dragon awakening from a long slumber, Chinatown is bursting its traditional Chatham Square boundaries, spreading north in Manhattan and sprawling over the metropolitan area to spawn satellite neighborhoods in Queens, Brooklyn, Staten Island and New Jersey. Indeed, it is not only Chinese who are expanding beyond what was in 1960 an
title: Satellite Chinatowns Burgeon Throughout New York

body: All her life, 40-year-old Diana Burns has lived in the same frame house in a working-class pocket of northwestern Brooklyn, a place where residents can laze beside a backyard fig tree and see the skyscrapers of Manhattan. She has also gone to the same Roman Catholic church all her life, St. Nicholas. Her parents were married in St. Nicholas and
title: PARISH HELPS SAVE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: A 14-year-old Brooklyn youth was killed, a pregnant woman was shot and partially paralyzed and two others were wounded early yesterday when gunfire erupted at a rap-music concert and dance in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said. The shootings, at the Uhuru Center, situated in an old armory at 357 Sumner Avenue, were among
title: YOUTH SLAIN AT A BROOKLYN DANCE; 7 OTHERS KILLED IN VIOLENCE IN CITY

body: The night of July 4, Kevin Haaz watched the fireworks display over New York Harbor and stayed out until 4 A.M. But there will be no such splurging now. title: FUND'S GIFT TO A 9-YEAR OLD: A SECOND FAMILY

title: BIT OF ITALY IN BROOKLYN:

body: ''Giglio'' in Italian means lily, but in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn this Sunday and next, it means a 65-foot-high, 8,000-pound tower that more than 100 men will lift and parade in the 99th Annual Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel and St. Paulinus. The baroquely decorated aluminum-frame structure, faced in papier-mache panels and topped by a
title: TALL TOWER IS PARADED IN FESTIVAL

body: The secret to knocking out your opponents, says Andrew J. body: JUST a 15-minute drive east from midtown Manhattan, Maspeth has managed to retain a friendly small-town atmosphere while offering the benefits of big city living. title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN; MASPETH

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: IN taking her camera to Metropolitan Avenue in the Williamsburg and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn, Christine Noschese was onto something. It's a neighborhood, we learn, in which Italians settled nearly a century ago, Poles about 60 years ago, blacks after World War II. It has been sliced up by the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and beaten up by all
title: SCREEN: BROOKLYN BARBRA

body: To the Editor: You should be commended for asking a long-overdue question: ''What $70,000 Buys for the Homeless'' (editorial, March 25). For starters, it buys a bus ride to the old Greenpoint Hospital in the Williamsburg-Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, where New York City has been sheltering hundreds of homeless men (over 600 at last count) since
title: Distribute Homeless Shelters Fairly Throughout New York City

body: When 24 men stepped off a bus from Manhattan to enter the city's newest shelter for the homeless, they were met by protesting residents of the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. ''Women and children, yes; men, no!'' one protest sign said. The 70-bed shelter was opening one month after the city told neighborhood residents and local officials that it
title: BROOKLYN RESIDENTS PROTEST SWITCH IN SHELTER PLAN

body: On Court Street near Borough Hall in Brooklyn yesterday, 50 people milled around a house trailer that had been converted to look like a kitchen. A match was lighted in a wastebasket and, seconds later, a sheet caught fire. The house trailer was in danger of burning down. Not to worry. A series of fire sprinklers extinguished the fire in 25 seconds.
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Sprinklers

body: Eli Whitney High School, a vocational school in Brooklyn that has been on the decline for more than a decade with waning attendance, failing grades and violence in its halls and classrooms, will be closed within two years, New York City school officials said yesterday. ''The question we asked is, 'Do parents have the confidence to send their child
title: A TROUBLED HIGH SCHOOL IN BROOKLYN WILL CLOSE

body: Quality and Value in Nuts While J. Wolsk & Company is not the easiest place to find, it's well worth the effort. At 81 Ludlow Street, between Delancey and Broome Streets, near the approach to the Williamsburg Bridge, the nut, dried fruit and candy store has been a Lower East Side institution since 1938. Two years ago, it moved from a cramped space
title: FOOD NOTES

body: A 27-year-old woman apparently drowned in the East River when she backed a van off a pier in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn late Friday night. Her boyfriend drowned when he dived in to try to rescue her. The van plunged off the pier at about 11:30 P.M. Friday when the woman, who was arguing about her driving ability with her boyfriend and
title: Woman Drives Van off a Pier; Friend Drowns in Rescue Bid

body: Following are the scores, released by the New York City Board of Education, on the reading tests given in the city's public elementary schools and junior high schools in April 1985. The center column shows the proportion of pupils in each school reading at or above grade level. The right-hand column gives each school's overall citywide ranking.
title: READING SCORES IN CITY'S ELEMENTARY AND JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOLS

body: For most of the world outside City Hall, Edward I. Koch must seem to be the most active person in that venerable building. For the small world inside, however, John Zissel more closely embodies omnipresence. And he is about to celebrate an anniversary at the hall that even Mayor Koch would envy - his 20th. title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY; Minding the Hall

body: To the Editor: Your Christmas Day editorial ''A Way Out of the Homeless Hotels'' introduces an initiative by entrepreneur Leonard Stern which defines a plan for involving the private sector in providing for the homeless. title: Letter: On Care of the Homeless; Looking Beyond Hotels and Shelters
